newsitem.title: BELGIUM: French Pixtech set for Feb 7 launch on Easdaq.
newsitem.headline: French Pixtech set for Feb 7 launch on Easdaq.

text.p: French flat-screen technology company Pixtech will become the sixth stock to be listed on new growth stocks market Easdaq when it begins trading on the pan-European exchange on February 7.
Subscriptions to the firm's public offer of up to 4.5 million shares, which began on January 23, close on February 3 when the stock's price will be fixed.

"The price fixing will be in a range of approximately $4 to $5, with reference to the stock's closing price on Nasdaq," Michel Birnbaum of Paris-based investment company Hambrecht & Quist Saint Dominique told a news conference on Wednesday.
"The company wants to widen the spectrum of investors, and Easdaq was the best way to do it," he added. Hambrecht & Quist Saint Dominique belongs to the syndicate placing the stock.
Pixtech delayed its initial planned launch on the fledgling European exchange from late last year due to poor stock market conditions on Wall Street and elsewhere, Birnbaum said.
On the U.S. Nasdaq market its shares closed at $6 on Tuesday, continuing a choppy recovery from $3-3/8 in mid-November. Introduced to Nasdaq in 1995 at $9.5, the stock peaked at $14 in February 1996.
Pixtech's executive vice president Francis Courreges said funds raised would mainly be used to finance a high-volume manufacturing process.

The firm designs, develops and manufactures field emission displays (FED) - a flat screen panel display which it says compares favourably to the liquid crystal display (LCD) alternative currently used widely, for example in portable computers.
The FED, it says, produces a better quality and brighter picture than LCD, uses less power and works in more extreme temperatures.

The FED panel works by placing a phosphor screen in front of a plate of millions of micron sized "microtips" which are attached to a cathode conductor sheet. Sandwiched between two glass plates, the panel is just 2.5 millimetres thick.
A coloured image is created by electrons striking the phosphor in the same way as with a television or computer monitor screen which uses a conventional cathode ray tube.
"Pixtech is at the stage where we are now turning to high-volume production," Courreges added, saying the company had a short term annual revenue goal of over $100 million.
Pixtech had total revenues of $11.5 million in 1995, when it made a net loss of $6.3 million.
